title: Gryffindor Characteristics: Pros, Cons, Famous Wizards & More

steps.title: Brave and courageous
steps.content: Brave and courageous Bold Gryffindors never shy away from a challenge, and they never let fear keep them from achieving their goals. If you’re a Gryffindor, you likely approach life with a fearless attitude, and you pride yourself on your courage. No matter what life throws at you, you believe in yourself and bravely charge toward success. [1] X Research source Bravery might be the first thing that comes to mind when you think of Gryffindor, but you can still have a nervous disposition and be courageous. For example, Neville Longbottom began the series as an anxious Gryffindor and grew into one of the heroes of the series. Gryffindors are often brave and bold in their ambition to succeed. People tend to associate ambition with Slytherin House, but Gryffindors can be very determined, too. Many Gryffindors in the Harry Potter series are ambitious and goal-oriented. Albus Dumbledore, for example, is one of the most successful wizards of all time who rose to the position of Headmaster at Hogwarts.

steps.title: Daring and adventurous
steps.content: Daring and adventurous Gryffindors typically lead adventurous lives. They aren’t content to play it safe or stay in their comfort zone. Instead, they prefer to seek exciting new experiences and live on the edge. [2] X Research source As a Gryffindor, you might love daring activities like traveling around the world or participating in extreme sports. If this sounds like you, you just might belong in Gryffindor House! When you’re traveling, you’d enjoy swimming with sharks, visiting an active volcano, or mountain-biking through treacherous terrain more than lounging around peacefully at a resort. With your thrill-seeking tendencies, your bucket list probably includes things like sky-diving or bungee jumping.

steps.title: Chivalrous and moral
steps.content: Chivalrous and moral In Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone , the Sorting Hat sings about the Gryffindor traits of “daring, nerve, and chivalry.” [3] X Research source Yes, Gryffindors will bravely charge into battle, but only for causes they believe to be moral and right. [4] X Research source If you have a strong moral code that you’ll stand up and fight for, there’s a good chance you’re a Gryffindor. Members of Hufflepuff House are most commonly associated with morality and having a strong sense of justice, but many Gryffindors also embody these traits. In the Harry Potter series, Harry himself is a Gryffindor who deeply values justice. Harry takes on the terrifying and difficult quest of defeating Lord Voldemort because he knows it’s the right thing to do for the good of the whole world.

steps.title: Confident and outgoing
steps.content: Confident and outgoing Gryffindors tend to be extroverts, and their self-confidence makes them great at making new friends. They aren’t afraid to be the center of attention, and they are often the life of the party. If you’re a bold, social person who is very comfortable in their own skin, there’s a good chance you belong in Gryffindor house. If you’re a Gryffindor, you’re likely bold and fearless in social situations that would make others nervous. For example, if you attend a party where you don’t know anyone, you won’t be a wallflower. You’ll confidently approach the other party-goers, introducing yourself and making conversation.

steps.title: Loyal and dependable
steps.content: Loyal and dependable Gryffindors also have pride in their house, and they’ve always got their fellow Gryffindor’s backs. When they make a friend, they’re loyal to the very end. If you take pride in your loyalty and dependability, you’d make a great Gryffindor! [5] X Research source Loyalty is typically associated with Hufflepuff House, but several Gryffindors in the Harry Potter series exhibit this trait as well. For example, Hermione and Ron stick by Harry’s side through thick and thin. They help Harry fight Lord Voldemort, even when the quest becomes perilous. They never abandon Harry, even when others question and mock him. Want to learn more about what makes a Gryffindor? Check out wikiHow's "What are Gryffindor traits besides heroism and bravery?" forum !

steps.title: Reckless
steps.content: Reckless Because Gryffindors are so brave, they can find themselves in some sticky situations. Courage is a virtue, but it can be dangerous to be too courageous without thinking things through. If you’re a brave Gryffindor who can be a bit too reckless at times, work on being patient , and make sure you take your time to make thoughtful decisions. [6] X Research source Not all Gryffindors are reckless. For example, Hermione Granger uses her Ravenclaw-like intelligence to weigh the pros and cons of risky actions like breaking school rules to brew Polyjuice Potion in The Chamber of Secrets . However, she chooses to press forward because it's the right thing to do, whereas a logical Ravenclaw might have stayed in their common room. You might find it helpful to practice mindfulness . This involves focusing on what you’re feeling in the present moment through practices like meditation. [7] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Mindfulness can help you become more self aware and stay in the moment so you can fight the impulse to rush into reckless decisions.

steps.title: Short-tempered
steps.content: Short-tempered Bold Gryffindors are known for their fiery sense of justice and their determination to fight for what’s right. These are definitely admirable traits, but Gryffindors can also be a bit hot-headed when it comes to their beliefs. [8] X Research source In the middle of a debate, they might say something insensitive and hurt someone’s feelings, or lose their cool and start yelling. If you’re a Gryffindor who has a short fuse, work on controlling your temper so you can communicate effectively . Learn active listening skills to avoid heated arguments. These include making eye contact, maintaining engaged body language, and taking turns speaking. This will help make sure you don’t dominate the conversation with your fiery Gryffindor energy!

steps.title: Arrogant
steps.content: Arrogant Members of other houses (like Hufflepuff) tend to be a bit more modest and humble about their achievements, but Gryffindors have no trouble accepting credit for their successes. This can be a good thing, but if left unchecked, it can also lead to arrogance or self-centeredness. [9] X Research source If you’re a Gryffindor, make sure to balance your confidence with humility . This could look like boasting less about your achievements, or giving more credit to others for the role they played in your success. It could also mean cheering friends and loved ones on when they reach their goals.

steps.title: Stubborn
steps.content: Stubborn Gryffindors are definitely passionate about their beliefs, and they’re willing to fight for them. This is an admirable quality, but it can also make Gryffindors very stubborn. Gryffindors are slow to admit when they’re wrong, and when they have an idea in their head, it’s hard to change their mind. [10] X Research source If you’re a stubborn Gryffindor, take the time to listen to others’ perspectives, and try to respect their opinions. Sometimes, their wisdom can help guide you on your own path.

steps.title: Savior complex
steps.content: Savior complex Because Gryffindors are naturally courageous and moral, they often end up as the heroes of their stories. For example, Harry Potter is “the chosen one” who is prophesied to save the whole wizarding world from Lord Voldemort. Although it’s admirable to fight for and protect others, Gryffindors can get a bit carried away with this. They sometimes end up developing a savior complex (a psychological need to save other people). This can be detrimental because it causes you to sacrifice your own needs for the needs of others to an excessive degree. [11] X Research source For example, you might stay up all night supporting a friend who is going through something, leaving you feeling tired and loopy at work the next day. Or, you could go out of your way to help a coworker finish a project, which keeps you from finishing your own tasks and leads to consequences at work. If you’re a Gryffindor who feels an excessive need to save other people, remember, you can’t pour from an empty cup, and you can’t take care of others if you aren’t taking care of yourself!

steps.title: Harry Potter
steps.content: Harry Potter Harry Potter himself is probably the most famous member of Gryffindor House. Throughout the series, Harry displays the Gryffindor traits of bravery, determination, and morality as he goes up against the most powerful dark wizard of all time, Lord Voldemort. Harry’s courage and goodness makes him not just “the chosen one,” but also a true Gryffindor. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Hermione Granger
steps.content: Hermione Granger Known as one of the most intelligent witches of her time, Hermione Granger is a very notable Gryffindor. With her impressive blend of intellect and courage, Hermione plays an important role in the fight against Voldemort. Her bravery and commitment to fighting for what’s right make her a true member of Gryffindor House. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Ron Weasley
steps.content: Ron Weasley Though Ron struggles to overcome some of his fears earlier in the series, he proves his true worth as a Gryffindor by the end. Ron stands firm at Harry’s side in the fight against Voldemort, revealing his courageous heart and strong moral compass. Along with the rest of the Weasley family, Ron is a valuable member of Gryffindor House. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Albus Dumbledore
steps.content: Albus Dumbledore The Headmaster of Hogwarts himself, Professor Dumbledore, is another notable member of Gryffindor. According to the lore of the series, Professor Dumbledore bravely fought and defeated one of the most dangerous wizards of all time, Gellert Grindelwald. He also plays a crucial role in taking down Lord Voldemort. [15] X Research source There’s no question that Albus Dumbledore is one of the bravest and most celebrated wizards in the Harry Potter series, which makes him the perfect example of a model Gryffindor.

steps.title: Minerva McGonagall
steps.content: Minerva McGonagall Professor McGonagall is the Head of Gryffindor House during Harry Potter’s time at Hogwarts. She is an incredibly talented witch who teaches Transfiguration. Professor McGonagall shows great bravery and morality throughout the series, especially at the Battle of Hogwarts in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows , during which she defends the school against Lord Voldemort. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Neville Longbottom
steps.content: Neville Longbottom Neville Longbottom begins as an unassuming character who seems to lack the courage and boldness of other Gryffindors. Over time, however, Neville proves to be one of the bravest Gryffindors in the whole series, and he ends up playing a crucial role in taking down Lord Voldemort. Neville’s story shows that there’s many different ways to be a true Gryffindor, and it proves that you should never judge a book by its cover. [17] X Research source
